Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

Hi Taylor,

On Jan 22, 2007, at 6:41 PM, Taylor Parsons wrote:

> REST url format for returning serialized data in formats other then  
> default.
>
> For example does any feel strongly about either of these two formats?

David Hansson certainly does. :-)  The former is now the default in  
Rails 1.2.

http://weblog.rubyonrails.org/2007/1/19/rails-1-2-rest-admiration- 
http-lovefest-and-utf-8-celebrations

That may not mean he's "right", but I tend to trust his instincts.   
Plus, Rails is (I think) the first major web app framework to  
wholeheartedly switch to a RESTful approach, so I think it provides a  
useful precedent.

That said, I can imagine cases where the latter would feel more  
natural or easy to code; but if you're unsure, I'd go with the former  
(and Rails).

-enp

>
> First approach parse the file file format as the switch for decide  
> how the caller wants the data formatted.
>  /baseURL/method/doc.rss
>  /baseURL/method/doc.json
>  /baseURL/method/doc.xml
>  /baseURL/method/doc.html
>
> Second approach the default return format would be html, and we add  
> in a feeds sub-dir and a file format to use as our switch.
>  /baseURL/feeds/rss/method/
>  /baseURL/feeds/json/method/
>  /baseURL/feeds/xml/method/


--Apple-Mail-5-134986305
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=ISO-8859-1
